summary: Maurice Hyman Halperin was a former OSS official and Boston University professor suspected of Soviet espionage and working for the Soviet government. He is mentioned in the context of investigations into American Communists in Mexico and his connections to individuals like James A. Perry, who was employed by the Agency. Halperin's file contains FBI and State Department documents, including reports and despatches related to him and associated individuals. The documents span from 1955 to 1962, indicating ongoing scrutiny of his activities and connections during this period. He is suspected of having ties to the Soviet Union.
significance: The significance of Maurice Hyman Halperin in the JFK context is primarily related to the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) reviewing his file as part of their investigation. His suspected ties to the Soviet Union and connections to individuals involved in espionage activities may have been of interest to the HSCA in exploring potential foreign involvement or influences related to the assassination.
